meanings.def: a hollow space in something solid or in the surface of something
examples: He dug a deep hole in the garden.
hole in something The bomb blew a huge hole in the ground.
Water had collected in the holes in the road.
She drilled a small hole in the wall.
I uprooted the tree and filled the hole with earth.
The snake disappeared down a hole.
There was water in the hole.
We dug a deep hole to bury the animals in.
We used cement to plug the holes.
He managed to dig out a small snow hole.
I've got a chocolate-bar-sized hole in my stomach.

meanings.def: a space or opening that goes all the way through something
examples: We drilled a hole through the wall.
The car was riddled with bullet holes.
The old blankets were full of holes.
hole in something There were holes in the knees of his trousers.
There's a gaping hole in the ceiling and rain is pouring onto my desk.
She punched two holes in each sheet of paper.
through a hole The children climbed through a hole in the fence.
She caught a fish through a hole in the ice.
He hadn't told us the whole story.
The camera moves and you see the whole of the palace.
The figure cut a round black hole in the ice of a lake.
He had worn a hole in the knees of his trousers.
I used a skewer to make an extra hole in my belt.
The missile had torn a jagged hole in the side of the ship.
The wall was full of bullet holes.
an operation for a hole in her heart

meanings.def: the home of a small animal
examples: a mouse hole
down a hole The story begins with Alice falling down a rabbit hole.

meanings.def: an unpleasant place to live or be in
examples: I am not going to bring up my child in this hole.

meanings.def: a hollow in the ground that you must get the ball into; one of the sections of a golf course with the tee at the beginning and the hole at the end
examples: The ball rolled into the hole and she had won.
an eighteen-hole golf course
He liked to play a few holes after work.
She won the first hole.
She won by one hole.

meanings.def: a fault or weakness in something such as a plan, law or story
examples: I don't believe what she says—her story is full of holes.
hole in something He was found not guilty because of holes in the prosecution case.

meanings.def: a place or position that needs to be filled because somebody/something is no longer there
examples: After his wife left, there was a gaping hole in his life.
Buying the new equipment left a big hole in the company's finances.

meanings.def: a secret advantage, for example a piece of information or a skill, that you are ready to use if you need to
if money burns a hole in your pocket, you want to spend it as soon as you have it
to get yourself into a bad situation that will be very difficult to get out of

examples: He had got himself into a hole and it was going to be difficult to get out of it.
We start the current fiscal year $30 million in the hole.

meanings.def: to use up a large amount of something that you have, especially money
examples: School fees can make a big hole in your savings.

meanings.def: to find the weak points in something such as a plan, suggestion, etc.
examples: It was easy to pick holes in his arguments.

meanings.def: a person who does not feel happy or comfortable in a particular situation, or who is not suitable for it

meanings.def: to make a hole or holes in something, especially a boat or ship
examples: be holed by something The ship had been holed by a missile.
be holed The hull was holed in several places.

meanings.def: to hit a golf ball into the hole
examples: hole something She holed a 25 foot putt.
hole (out) She holed out from 25 feet.
